caseName: Jennings v. Glen Alden Coal Co.
caseNameFull: Jennings, Appellant, v. Glen Alden Coal Company
judge: Drew, Stern, Stearne, Bell, Chidsey, Musmanno

opinions.snippet: Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Drew, The proper determination of this case rests on the application of Section 339 of the Restatement, Torts to the evidence presented at the trial. The learned trial judge held that plaintiff had failed to bring himself within the scope of that rule and accordingly entered a nonsuit. From an order denying a motion to remove the nonsuit, plaintiff has appealed.

Dissenting Opinion by
Mr. Justice Musmanno:
The learned trial Judge below erred in stating to the jury when he entered the nonsuit against the parent plaintiffs that — “. . . If we were to permit a recovery in this case, we would have to impose upon the owners of land adjoining rivers, lakes, streams, ponds and pools of all kinds the burden of either drying up these waters or surrounding them with fences and the li

caseName: Bartleson v. Glen Alden Coal Co.
caseNameFull: Bartleson Et Al. v. Glen Alden Coal Company, Appellant, Et Al.
judge: Maxey, Drew, Linn, Stern, Patterson, Stearne, Jones

opinions.snippet:
I cannot join in the conclusion of the majority. As I view this case, there is nothing in the record showing *Page 530 
a breach of duty by defendant for which it should be held liable in damages.
The Restatement of the Law of Torts, Section 339, which we adopted in Thompson v. Reading Co., 343 Pa. 585, 23 A.2d 729;Altenbach v. Leh. Val. R. R. Co., <cross_referen

posture:
Appeals, Nos. 241 and 242, Jan. T., 1948, from judgments of Common Pleas, Luzerne Co., March T., 1947, No. 184, in case of William Bartleson et al. v. Glen Alden Coal Company et al. Judgments affirmed.

Trespass for personal injuries. Before FARRELL, J.

Verdict for minor plaintiff in the sum of $10,000 and for plaintiff parents in the sum of $3,000; defendants' motion for judgment n. o. v. denied, opinion by PINOLA, J., dissenting opinion by VALENTINE, P. J. and judgments entered on the verdicts. Defendant coal company appealed.
